Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Chemistry Connections for Community College Students at the University of California, San Diego
Award.AbstractNarration:
This National Science Foundation award from the Division of Chemistry (CHE) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) site led by Professors Haim Weizman and Stacey Brydges both at the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of California, San Diego. The "4Cs @ UCSD" program offers 10 first-year (or the equivalent) students attending the extensive network of two-year colleges (2YCs) within commuting distance of UC San Diego an intensive and integrated early undergraduate research experience in the chemical sciences, at the frontiers of materials synthesis, human health and disease, energy and environmental science. Apprenticeships span a year, with an introduction to research methods in the Spring prior to full and active immersion in a research laboratory during the 10-weeks of summer and 10-week(ends) of the Fall academic quarter, and are buttressed by enrichment activities that include research seminars, industrial field trips, academic and professional skills workshops, and final presentations at the Undergraduate Research Symposium in Chemistry at UC San Diego in the subsequent Spring. Formally trained mentorship teams comprising 2YC/UC San Diego faculty and graduate student role models support REU fellows at all stages of this program.

Overall, it is intended that this REU site will serve to: (1) broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in undergraduate research; (2) enable the successful transition of community college students from associate degrees to baccalaureate and graduate programs in the chemical sciences; (3) engage graduate students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty in a mentoring process that leads to more effective and inclusive research training and practices; and, (4) expand access to key academic resources - people, facilities, and programs - and thus, opportunities for authentic collaborations and curricular innovations linking research and education at all institutions involved. Collectively, these initiatives will contribute to the growth of the science pipeline, the progress of chemical research and educational reform, and the achievement of national goals to recruit and retain a more diverse scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemistry Connections for Community College Students (4Cs@UCSD) offered first-year students attending the broad network of two-year colleges within commuting distance of UC San Diego an early research experience in the chemical sciences.  The program was designed to help develop new research skills, scientific knowledge and professional preparation that will enable a successful transition to a four-year university.  The program specifically targeted students with limited exposure to academic opportunities with the intention that early exposure to an immersive research experience will motivate and support their higher education endeavor. Following recruitment efforts that included UCSD Chemistry & Biochemistry faculty visits to local community colleges, the program hosted 29 students over three years from six colleges: Cuyamaca, Mesa, Mira Costa, Miramar, Palomar and Southwestern. Of the participants, 80% were of non-traditional school age (i.e. 24-30+ yrs old), over 50% females, 70%  racial/ethnic populations underrepresented in STEM fields including first generation students and 30% veterans of the U.S. Armed Forces.

Students were immersed in a research projects over a 10-week summer period and participated in variety of Community Building (challenge course, group socials) and Academic enrichment activities (weekly faculty research seminars, lunch with the speaker, biweekly academic skills workshops and industrial field trips. The program culminated with oral presentations at the UCSD Summer Research Conference.

Creating a commuter-based program had several major advantages: 1. It allowed students to continue supporting their  families while attending the program, 2. Increase the number of participants due to cost-savings, 3. Ability to continue the research during the subsequent academic year and additional activities to support transfer. Research and mentoring extends into the next academic quarters, allowing REU Fellows to build on their summer apprenticeship.

Over 3 years the program hosted 29 students. A national survey of students participating in summer research programs (SURE, Summer Undergraduate Research Experiences) revealed that 4Cs students ranked the program higher than the national average on almost every measure. 4Cs participants transferred successfully from their community colleges to top universities. Several students already continued to graduate school programs.

About 50% of the REU fellows chose to continue their research beyond the summer program. Several students published their scientific finding as research papers in leading journals and presented posters at National Meetings of the American Chemical Society.  

 

Beyond research experiences, 4Cs@UCSD created novel modules for developing scientific communication skills.
